narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Same as 344L. Confidence on lab bench, confidence giving job and chalk talks. Each student gave a 30 minute presentation about a paper. Sounds crazy but actually it was a lot more doable than I had thought!
application of research techniques in first course, and about cell biology of SARS-CoV-2 and Alzheimer's through job talks

MCDB 345L builds upon the work done in MCDB 344. I think the specific techniques and experiments performed in 344 and 345 vary by year. What was different for 345 was that our job talks were extended to 30 minutes instead of the 15-minute talks we gave in 344.

You will learn lots about Alzheimers, how to give a "job talk" (research presentation), how to do protein preps and how to perform a blot, how to do PCR and how to run agarose gels. You will also learn more broadly about the research environment and how to be an effective research scientist.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is taught wonderfully. It fosters a collaborative learning environment that the vast majority of Yale courses lack. You will learn loads. My only recommendation would be that it would be nice to receive written feedback on our presentations. Take the course if you can--but apply early! Email Prof Wolenski ASAP.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes yes yes!! We ate out for lunch on the last day of class... so fun :)

Taking this course was one of the best decisions I've made. If you are lucky enough to get a spot (email early!!) you will not regret taking it. It's a wonderful way to learn cell biology, meet friends, and have a wonderful and close experience with a kind and thoughtful professor.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
